captions.text:
There's a certain set of humans in the world
that hears the "Why do I have to brush my

teeth?" question pretty much every evening.
Right around, say 8 o'clock. Almost always

posed by the offspring of that person. Usually
under the age of 10. And in those instances,

the answer almost always is "Because your
mother and I told you to!" But one of our

followers on Tumblr asked a more thoughtful
version of this same question: "Why do I have
to brush my teeth from an evolutionary perspective?"

The answer is still because your mother and
I told you to! Okay, actually, it is a pretty

cool question. Cause our primate ancestors
didn't brush their teeth, and surely they

didn't have their teeth falling out all over
the place, and they weren't dying of gingivitis.

Right? Right. Well some of them did, but not
all of them.

I mean all animals that have teeth likely
have to deal with tooth decay to some extent.

Veterinarians will tell you that they see
cats and dogs all the time that have cavities

or caries, as scientists call them. And biologists
have reported finding wild animals as diverse

as lions, and bears, and orcas with huge painful
abscesses. But part of why we have to brush

our teeth has to do with longevity. Most wild
primates just don't live long enough for things

like tooth and gum disease to catch up with
them. We do.

For example, the life expectancy of our nearest
evolutionary relative the chimpanzee is just

40 years in the wild. In captivity, though,
it's around 60. And tooth decay can become

a problem with captive apes and monkeys, which
is why keepers have to regularly brush their
teeth. Which I imagine is not super fun.

Our life expectancy, meanwhile, is around
80 in most industrialized countries, which

means we're living twice as long as our closest
genetic relatives. So we gotta keep our parts

working for a lot longer than they were probably
supposed to work. And this means brushing

your teeth a couple times a day. Consider
it a small price to pay for having benefited
so much from evolution.

But beyond that, by far the most important
factor that effects our dental health, as

opposed to that of our genetic predecessors,
is our diet. Most primates live quite nicely

on diets of fruits, and seeds, and nuts, and
leaves. And in the case of chimps, the occasional

insect or piece of meat. But since we started
cultivating grain some 12,000 years ago, our

diets have become totally dominated by starches
and the simple sugars that they contain. The

bacteria that form cavities really love these
sugars, and for the same reason that we do:they

are a very readily accessible form of energy.
So the more sugar you eat, the more susceptible

you are to tooth decay. And this is true not
just for leftover Halloween candy and Coca-Colas,

but any kind of cereal grain you can think
of like wheat, or oats, or corn. The evolutionary

connection between tooth decay and agriculture
is so distinct in fact that anthropologists

can actually determine whether a culture started
farming in part by studying when they started

to get cavities. Again, it's just part of
the cost of being such an awesomely successful

species. Now seriously, brush your teeth!
Go to bed! It's late; you've got school in
the morning!

Thanks for watching this SciShow Quick Question.
If you have a question that you would like

us to answer, you can ask us on our tumblr,
or our facebook, or our twitter, or in the

comments of this video. And if you want to
keep getting smarter with us, you can go to
youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

title: Why Do I Have to Brush My Teeth?

We doomed to have bad teeth because our diet has changed so how do we fix 
it. I like the idea of the 2008 iGem Team who blocked the receptors used by 
the bad bacteria Streptococcos Mutans to hold tight to the teeth. I would 
love to know if there are other great inventions who would help my teeth to 
stay withe and shiny for the rest of my life.﻿
comments.author: Christoph Geske

comments.text:
Several years ago, a researcher developed a modified form of S. mutans 
which, instead of excreting tooth-decaying acid, excreted a compound 
harmless to teeth and also deadly to standard S. mutans which excrete 
acid.  This meant that all you would need to do is swish a solution with 
these bacteria in it around in your mouth one time in your life and you 
would be decay-free forever.  Unfortunately, he ran out of funding and the 
project was abandoned.  While such a development would pretty much destroy 
the dental industry (almost all of their money is made due to tooth decay), 
it would have improved the lives of perhaps billions of people.  I am 
astounded that his work did not get developed further.  Hopefully someday 
it will get picked up again.﻿

comments.text: Why do rough ER have ribosomes and Smooth ER do not?﻿
comments.author: Ronald Kueker

comments.text:
Short, highly simplified answer: Rough ER produce more protein than Smooth 
ER, which produce more fatty molecules. Thus rough ER need ribosomes to 
produce the amount of protein that they do.

Evolution is a proven fact, like I said, get a microscope, find any kinds

their offspring whether sexual or asexual, they will start to show new 
traits. Have you ever wondered why some antibiotics can't be used anymore? 
Because the organisms have evolved to survive the medicine. Why are there 
so many traits even with humans that have only surfaced over the past few 
centuries? Traits that we never had before.How did white skinned humans 
come to be? Why do we have useless traits, organs that don't do anything? 
Evolution is a topic being studied literally all the time, you can even go 
outside and study it right now, but I guess if you want to be blind to the 
fact than so be it.

comments.author: Tigersaur

comments.text:
Even if you're religious in any way that doesn't mean you can't believe in 
evolution. The only time you can't believe in evolution is if you think 
literally everything in the entire world and universe is perfect in every 
way and never ever has the need to change no matter the circumstances. 
Evolution is an observable factor of life everyday, ever hear of 
microorganisms? Why would we look at fossils to observe evolution when we 
can look at living life? Even humans have very clear signs of our evolution 
over time, parts of us that once had purpose and no longer does such 
as:body hair, wisdom teeth, the appendix, male nipples, the erector pili, 
coccyx (tail bone), Plica semilunaris, Darwin’s point (flap of skin on 
ear), vomeronasal organ, and auricular muscles. All of those are parts of 
our "perfect" bodies that have no purpose at all, once maybe, now no, and 
many of which are major faults, like the wisdom teeth and appendix that 
does more than nothing, they can actually cause infections, the appendix 
can burst being very fatal. I'll admit I'm not a religious person, but I'm 
not atheist, I realize that the world isn't perfect, the universe isn't 
perfect, and that humanity is a small little spec within a small solar 
system with an average star, on the edge of an average galaxy in a sea of 
literally over 500 billion other galaxies in the known universe all of 
which that has billions of stars, and trillions of planets. Evolution is 
not a lie, you can believe in God, but please you can't deny the truth, 
really just buy a microscope, find bacteria or any other microorganism and 
observe it for a little while, maybe change the environment a bit, and you 
will literally SEE that evolution is truth. Also many scientists are very 
religious individuals, science is not the destroyer of religion, this isn't 
the 18th century anymore, you should really understand that. You believe 
everything is perfect, evolution is a lie, and you are right and no one 
else can be, what's next do you think that anyone else who follows any 
other religion is the devil and is going to burn in hell just because they 
have a different opinion than you? Please tell me who told you and provided 
evidence that your religion is the one and only right one in the world. 
Hell even most Christians realize the faults in their religion, hence why 
there's hundreds of different types on it.

comments.text:
Pretty sure that when archaeologists study ancient teeth to determine when 
a culture started farming they do it because ancient civilisations didn't 
have access to advanced milling techniques that we do now. The easiest way 
to crush something and make flour out of wheat is just by crushing it 
between two stones, with the side effect that there are tiny bits of stone 
in the flour... and eating stony bread every day of your life leaves quite 
the trace on your teeth.

That's the impression I've been having. Perhaps I'm wrong or both are true?﻿
comments.author: Shaeress

comments.text:
I wish he went over toothpastes. I used to brush my teeth with fluoridated 
toothpaste, but my teeth started to hurt. I went to a non-fluoridated 
toothpaste (it had sodium lauryl sulfate (foaming agent) in it) and 
actually hurt way worse. Then I went to baking soda brushing and I will 
never go back to toothpaste. I don't see any reason for adding fluoride to 
toothpaste or drinking water. Europe has stopped adding fluoride to their 
products over the years, and I hope the United States follows. There's no 
reason to add a toxic by-product of other chemical processes (fluoride is a 
leftover from the fertilizer industry) to our stuff for "tooth health".﻿
